Dmisc 0.4.3

    • Cut Cut Cut

Cut Cut Cut

Why cut3?

Source: vignettes/cut3.Rmd
cut3.Rmd
library(Dmisc)

Sometimes it is interesting to convert a numeric variable into a categorical one. For these purposes, there are several functions in R. Here we present some of them and how they compare to cut3.

Breaks

The first and most important argument of these functions is breaks, which consists of an indicative of how are constructed the intervals in which the desired variable is to be cut.

A single number

If the breaks argument consists of a single number, this is interpreted as the number of breaks to be applied to the variable of interest.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

tbl$age = cut(tbl$age, breaks = 2)
tbl
#>            age freq
#> 1  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 2  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 3  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 4  (0.991,5.5]    4
#> 5  (0.991,5.5]    3
#> 6     (5.5,10]    3
#> 7     (5.5,10]    5
#> 8     (5.5,10]    3
#> 9     (5.5,10]    4
#> 10    (5.5,10]    5

The same could be done using cut3, the only difference is that the latter is designed to work with dataframe instead of vectors, so the syntax could be a bit different, but the result is the same.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2)
#>            age freq
#> 1  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 2  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 3  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 4  (0.991,5.5]    4
#> 5  (0.991,5.5]    3
#> 6     (5.5,10]    3
#> 7     (5.5,10]    5
#> 8     (5.5,10]    3
#> 9     (5.5,10]    4
#> 10    (5.5,10]    5

A numeric vector

Another option available in both functions is to supply a numeric vector. In this case, the values contained in said vector will be treated as the cut-off points for the construction of the intervals in which the variable in question has to be cut.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

tbl$age = cut(tbl$age, breaks = c(0, 5, 10))
tbl
#>       age freq
#> 1   (0,5]    5
#> 2   (0,5]    5
#> 3   (0,5]    5
#> 4   (0,5]    4
#> 5   (0,5]    3
#> 6  (5,10]    3
#> 7  (5,10]    5
#> 8  (5,10]    3
#> 9  (5,10]    4
#> 10 (5,10]    5

Again, the same can be achieved with the cut3 function.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = c(0, 5, 10))
#>       age freq
#> 1   (0,5]    5
#> 2   (0,5]    5
#> 3   (0,5]    5
#> 4   (0,5]    4
#> 5   (0,5]    3
#> 6  (5,10]    3
#> 7  (5,10]    5
#> 8  (5,10]    3
#> 9  (5,10]    4
#> 10 (5,10]    5

It is important to note that this vector of values must contain an initial value that is less than the minimum of the variable and a last value greater than or equal to the maximum of the variable. This is so due to the way in which the intervals are constructed.

Note in the label of the created variable (0,5] that the lower limit of the interval is open (, which means that only values greater than 0 are included. You can change this behavior, and do the first range closed using the argument include.lowest. While the upper bound is closed], which means that onlyvalues less than or equal to 5 are included.

If the vector of values does not meet the criteria described above, the values that do not fit in any interval will be marked as NA in the resulting variable.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = c(1, 5, 10))
#>       age freq
#> 1    <NA>    5
#> 2   (1,5]    5
#> 3   (1,5]    5
#> 4   (1,5]    4
#> 5   (1,5]    3
#> 6  (5,10]    3
#> 7  (5,10]    5
#> 8  (5,10]    3
#> 9  (5,10]    4
#> 10 (5,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = c(1, 5, 10), include.lowest = T)
#>       age freq
#> 1   [1,5]    5
#> 2   [1,5]    5
#> 3   [1,5]    5
#> 4   [1,5]    4
#> 5   [1,5]    3
#> 6  (5,10]    3
#> 7  (5,10]    5
#> 8  (5,10]    3
#> 9  (5,10]    4
#> 10 (5,10]    5

If for some reason the minimum and maximum values of the variable are not known a priori, the -Inf andInf values can be used for these purposes. Although this should be avoided as it decrease information from the label of the resulting variable.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = c(-Inf, 5, Inf))
#>         age freq
#> 1  (-Inf,5]    5
#> 2  (-Inf,5]    5
#> 3  (-Inf,5]    5
#> 4  (-Inf,5]    4
#> 5  (-Inf,5]    3
#> 6  (5, Inf]    3
#> 7  (5, Inf]    5
#> 8  (5, Inf]    3
#> 9  (5, Inf]    4
#> 10 (5, Inf]    5

Additionally, it is essential that the values of said vector be unique.

Functions

One of the main novelties of cut3 () compared to cut () is that the vector of breaks can be a function that generates the numerical vector of the cuts, or preferably, a vector that includes the minimum values and maximum, and said function.

The most common use case for this functionality is perhaps if you want to use quantiles to divide the variable.

For these purposes, the bf_args argument must be used in which additional arguments are specified, which must be passed to the function used to construct the breakpoints.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = quantile, bf_args = list(x = tbl$age))
#>           age freq
#> 1        <NA>    5
#> 2    (1,3.25]    5
#> 3    (1,3.25]    5
#> 4  (3.25,5.5]    4
#> 5  (3.25,5.5]    3
#> 6  (5.5,7.75]    3
#> 7  (5.5,7.75]    5
#> 8   (7.75,10]    3
#> 9   (7.75,10]    4
#> 10  (7.75,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = quantile, bf_args = list(x = tbl$age), include.lowest = T)
#>           age freq
#> 1    [1,3.25]    5
#> 2    [1,3.25]    5
#> 3    [1,3.25]    5
#> 4  (3.25,5.5]    4
#> 5  (3.25,5.5]    3
#> 6  (5.5,7.75]    3
#> 7  (5.5,7.75]    5
#> 8   (7.75,10]    3
#> 9   (7.75,10]    4
#> 10  (7.75,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = c(0, quantile), bf_args = list(x = tbl$age))
#>           age freq
#> 1       (0,1]    5
#> 2    (1,3.25]    5
#> 3    (1,3.25]    5
#> 4  (3.25,5.5]    4
#> 5  (3.25,5.5]    3
#> 6  (5.5,7.75]    3
#> 7  (5.5,7.75]    5
#> 8   (7.75,10]    3
#> 9   (7.75,10]    4
#> 10  (7.75,10]    5

Labels

As you may have already noticed in the previous examples, the data labels of the resulting variable are constructed using the corresponding interval notation. However, this behavior can be overridden by supplying the labels = F argument. In this case, a simple autoincrementing number will be used to name the intervals.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2)
#>            age freq
#> 1  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 2  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 3  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 4  (0.991,5.5]    4
#> 5  (0.991,5.5]    3
#> 6     (5.5,10]    3
#> 7     (5.5,10]    5
#> 8     (5.5,10]    3
#> 9     (5.5,10]    4
#> 10    (5.5,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2, labels = F)
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    1    5
#> 3    1    5
#> 4    1    4
#> 5    1    3
#> 6    2    3
#> 7    2    5
#> 8    2    3
#> 9    2    4
#> 10   2    5

Additionally, you can supply a vector specifying the labels you want to use in the construction of the variable. Labels will be assigned in the order they are specified. Also, the number of labels must be exactly equal to the number of resulting bins.

tbl <- data.frame(
  age = 1:10,
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    age freq
#> 1    1    5
#> 2    2    5
#> 3    3    5
#> 4    4    4
#> 5    5    3
#> 6    6    3
#> 7    7    5
#> 8    8    3
#> 9    9    4
#> 10  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2)
#>            age freq
#> 1  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 2  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 3  (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 4  (0.991,5.5]    4
#> 5  (0.991,5.5]    3
#> 6     (5.5,10]    3
#> 7     (5.5,10]    5
#> 8     (5.5,10]    3
#> 9     (5.5,10]    4
#> 10    (5.5,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2, labels = c("Menor o igual que 5", "Mayor a 5"))
#>                    age freq
#> 1  Menor o igual que 5    5
#> 2  Menor o igual que 5    5
#> 3  Menor o igual que 5    5
#> 4  Menor o igual que 5    4
#> 5  Menor o igual que 5    3
#> 6            Mayor a 5    3
#> 7            Mayor a 5    5
#> 8            Mayor a 5    3
#> 9            Mayor a 5    4
#> 10           Mayor a 5    5

Groups

Another addition to cut3 () consists of being able to define different cuts for different groups. This is especially useful when breaks are specified with functions.

tbl <- data.frame(
  sex = c(rep("M", 5), rep("F", 5)),
  age = c(1:5, 6:10),
  freq = c(5,5,5,4,3,3,5,3,4,5)
)

tbl
#>    sex age freq
#> 1    M   1    5
#> 2    M   2    5
#> 3    M   3    5
#> 4    M   4    4
#> 5    M   5    3
#> 6    F   6    3
#> 7    F   7    5
#> 8    F   8    3
#> 9    F   9    4
#> 10   F  10    5

cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2)
#>    sex         age freq
#> 1    M (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 2    M (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 3    M (0.991,5.5]    5
#> 4    M (0.991,5.5]    4
#> 5    M (0.991,5.5]    3
#> 6    F    (5.5,10]    3
#> 7    F    (5.5,10]    5
#> 8    F    (5.5,10]    3
#> 9    F    (5.5,10]    4
#> 10   F    (5.5,10]    5
cut3(tbl, var_name = "age", breaks = 2, groups = "sex")
#>    sex       age freq
#> 1    M (0.996,3]    5
#> 2    M (0.996,3]    5
#> 3    M (0.996,3]    5
#> 4    M     (3,5]    4
#> 5    M     (3,5]    3
#> 6    F     (6,8]    3
#> 7    F     (6,8]    5
#> 8    F     (6,8]    3
#> 9    F    (8,10]    4
#> 10   F    (8,10]    5
